source.name: City of Chicago Department of Streets and Sanitation
source.notes: Based on official Chicago Blue Cart recycling program accepted materials list and Chicago Recycles guidelines.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Chicago accepts plastics #1-#5 and #7
Do not bag recyclables — all items go loose in the blue cart
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid still in them
Don't put recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic containers (#1-#5, #7)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Check for recycling number #1-#5 or #7
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Chicago accepts rigid plastic containers numbered #1-#5 and #7
#6 plastics (polystyrene/styrofoam) are NOT accepted
commonMistakes: No #6 plastics (styrofoam) in the blue cart
No black plastic takeout containers

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids (recycle lids separately)
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Chicago DOES accept glass curbside in the blue cart — unlike some other cities
All colors of glass accepted (clear, green, brown)
commonMistakes: Don't include broken drinking glasses or window glass — those go in trash
Don't include ceramics or pottery

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
No need to crush cans
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Aluminum foil and pie tins
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Ball up foil pieces into a fist-sized ball
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Clean aluminum foil and foil pans/pie tins are accepted in Chicago's blue cart program
Must be clean — heavily soiled foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle foil caked with baked-on food
Small scraps can fall through sorting — ball them up

materials.name: Steel / tin cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Use a magnet test — steel cans stick to magnets, aluminum doesn't
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food still in them

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials (bubble wrap, styrofoam)
Place flat beside or in blue cart
notes: Chicago requires cardboard be flattened
Large boxes can be placed beside the blue cart
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food
Remove styrofoam inserts and plastic tape

materials.name: Cereal and food boxes
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove plastic liner bag (trash the liner)
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Thin paperboard/chipboard boxes are accepted in Chicago's blue cart
commonMistakes: Don't forget to remove plastic liner bags
Don't include boxes with heavy wax coating (like frozen food boxes)

materials.name: Paper towel and toilet paper rolls
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
notes: Cardboard tubes are accepted in Chicago recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include the used paper towels — just the cardboard tube

materials.name: Newspaper
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
No need to remove inserts or staples
notes: Newspaper and inserts are all accepted
commonMistakes: Don't put newspapers in plastic bags before recycling

materials.name: Office paper
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
Staples and paper clips are OK
notes: Most clean, dry paper is recyclable in Chicago
commonMistakes: Don't include paper towels or tissues
Don't shred paper if possible — shredded paper is harder to recycle

materials.name: Junk mail and envelopes
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
Window envelopes are OK — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: All mail paper is accepted in Chicago blue cart recycling
commonMistakes: Don't shred unless necessary for privacy

materials.name: Magazines and catalogs
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
Glossy paper is accepted
notes: Chicago accepts glossy magazines and catalogs
commonMistakes: Don't remove covers or binding

materials.name: Phone books
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
notes: Phone books are fully recyclable in Chicago
commonMistakes: Don't bag them in plastic

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place loose in blue cart
Can also be used to collect other paper recyclables
notes: Paper bags are accepted in Chicago's blue cart program
commonMistakes: Don't include paper bags soaked with grease or food

materials.name: File folders
instructions: Remove any metal fasteners if possible
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Manila and colored file folders are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include plastic hanging file folders

materials.name: Beverage cartons
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap if it has one
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Beverage cartons (milk, juice, soy milk, broth) are accepted in Chicago blue cart recycling
commonMistakes: Don't flatten cartons

materials.name: Wrapping paper
instructions: Plain paper wrapping paper: place loose in blue cart
Do the scrunch test — if it stays scrunched, it's recyclable paper
Metallic, glittery, or foil wrapping paper: trash
notes: Only plain paper wrapping paper is accepted in Chicago recycling
Metallic or glitter wrap is not recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't assume all wrapping paper is recyclable
Remove tape, bows, and ribbons before recycling

materials.name: Paper greeting cards
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
Remove any glitter, foil, or battery-powered components first
notes: Plain paper greeting cards are accepted in Chicago blue cart recycling
commonMistakes: Don't recycle cards with glitter — the glitter contaminates recycling
Musical cards with batteries go in trash

materials.name: Beverage carrier / drink holder
instructions: Place loose in blue cart
notes: Cardboard beverage carriers are recyclable in Chicago
commonMistakes: Plastic ring carriers should be cut and trashed

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate if in good condition — Chicago Public Library, Open Books, or thrift stores
If damaged, recycle paper pages in blue cart
Remove hardcover bindings with glossy laminate (trash them)
notes: Open Books Chicago (two locations) accepts used books for literacy programs
Donating is always better than recycling
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in trash

materials.name: Aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Do not puncture or crush
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Only fully empty aerosol cans are accepted
Non-empty aerosols are hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if can still has pressure or product
Full or partially full aerosols go to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility

materials.name: Styrofoam / Polystyrene (#6)
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Styrofoam / #6 plastic is NOT accepted in Chicago's blue cart recycling
notes: #6 plastics including all forms of polystyrene and styrofoam are explicitly excluded from Chicago's blue cart program
This includes foam cups, foam takeout containers, foam meat trays, packing peanuts, and styrofoam coolers
commonMistakes: Don't put any styrofoam in the blue cart — it contaminates the recycling stream
Packing peanuts are also styrofoam and go in trash

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Do NOT put in blue cart
Take clean, dry bags to a retail store drop-off (Jewel-Osco, Mariano's, Target)
Otherwise place in trash (black cart)
notes: Loose plastic bags jam Chicago's recycling machinery and cause costly shutdowns
Many Jewel-Osco and Mariano's locations in Chicago accept plastic bags for store drop-off recycling
commonMistakes: NEVER bag your recyclables in plastic bags — items must go loose in the blue cart
Don't put any film plastic, shrink wrap, or cling wrap in the blue cart

materials.name: Diapers and feminine products
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Not recyclable or compostable
notes: Diapers and feminine hygiene products are explicitly listed as NOT accepted in Chicago's blue cart
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart or any recycling

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Or donate to dry cleaners or thrift stores
notes: Hangers (all types) are explicitly NOT accepted in Chicago's blue cart recycling
Wire hangers tangle in sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't put any type of hanger in the blue cart

materials.name: Construction debris
instructions: NOT accepted in blue cart or black cart for large amounts
Hire a private hauler for large renovation debris
Small amounts can go in black cart trash
notes: Construction and demolition debris is explicitly excluded from Chicago's recycling program
For large projects, rent a dumpster from a private waste hauler
commonMistakes: Don't put construction materials in the blue cart

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Take to the City of Chicago Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Facility is free for Chicago residents
Latex paint: can also dry it out completely with kitty litter, then trash the solidified paint
Oil-based paint and spray paint must go to the facility
notes: The Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St. is open Tuesday–Saturday
Paint is explicitly listed as NOT accepted in Chicago's blue cart program
Never pour paint down the drain or into storm sewers
commonMistakes: Don't put paint cans (full or empty) in the blue cart
Don't pour paint down drains or into alleys

materials.name: Unnumbered hard plastics
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Unnumbered and hard reusable plastics are NOT recyclable in Chicago
notes: Items without a recycling number (#1-#7) are not accepted in the blue cart
This includes toys, toothbrushes, garden hoses, plastic utensils, and hard reusable bottles like Nalgene
commonMistakes: Don't put hard reusable water bottles (Nalgene, baby bottles) in the blue cart
Just because something is plastic doesn't mean it's recyclable

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Metallized plastic film is not recyclable
notes: The shiny interior is aluminum bonded to plastic — not separable for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart — the shiny look does not make it aluminum

materials.name: Candy wrappers
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Metallized plastic film is not recyclable in Chicago
notes: Candy wrappers look metallic but are multi-layer plastic, not aluminum
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart or compost

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Lined paper cup: trash (black cart)
Plastic lid: place in blue cart if #1-#5
Paper sleeve: place in blue cart
notes: The plastic or wax lining on paper cups prevents them from being recycled as paper
Separate the lid and sleeve — those parts may be recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put lined paper cups in the blue cart

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: Remove any leftover food
If the box has light grease stains, it can still go in the blue cart
If heavily soaked with grease and cheese, tear off the clean top (recycle) and trash the greasy bottom
notes: Chicago's blue cart program accepts pizza boxes with light grease
Tear off the heavily soiled parts and recycle the clean portions
commonMistakes: Don't throw the whole box in trash — at least the clean lid is recyclable
Don't leave food scraps in the box

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag, then put the bag in the blue cart
Do not put loose shredded paper directly in the blue cart
notes: Loose shredded paper blows away and clogs sorting equipment
Containing it in a paper bag keeps it together through the recycling process
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the blue cart
Don't use a plastic bag — use a paper bag

materials.name: Food scraps
instructions: Chicago does NOT have curbside composting for food scraps
Take food scraps to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location
Drop-off sites are at select Chicago Public Library branches and Department of Streets and Sanitation (DSS) facilities
If no drop-off is convenient, food scraps go in trash (black cart)
notes: Chicago's Food Scrap Drop-Off Program operates at approximately 33 locations citywide
Accepted items at drop-offs: fruit, vegetables, coffee grounds, eggshells, bread, grains, and other plant-based food waste
Meat and dairy are NOT accepted at most drop-off sites — check your specific location
commonMistakes: Chicago does NOT have curbside composting — don't expect a green bin for food
Check chicagocompost.org or chicago.gov for current drop-off locations and hours

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
instructions: Take to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location (Chicago Public Library branches and DSS facilities)
If no drop-off is convenient, place in trash (black cart)
notes: Chicago does not have curbside composting
Food Scrap Drop-Off sites accept fruit and vegetable scraps
commonMistakes: Don't expect a green composting bin — Chicago doesn't offer curbside composting

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
instructions: Take to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location
If no drop-off is convenient, place in trash (black cart)
notes: Vegetable scraps are accepted at Chicago's Food Scrap Drop-Off locations
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Take to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location
Coffee grounds and paper filters accepted at drop-off sites
If no drop-off is convenient, place in trash (black cart)
notes: Coffee grounds are one of the most common items at Chicago's food scrap drop-offs
commonMistakes: Check that tea bags are paper, not plastic mesh — only paper accepted
Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Eggshells
instructions: Take to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location
Crush eggshells for easier transport
If no drop-off is convenient, place in trash (black cart)
notes: Eggshells are accepted at Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off sites
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart
examples: Egg carton (paper — recycle in blue cart)

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Most Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off locations do NOT accept meat, bones, or dairy
notes: Unlike cities with industrial composting (e.g., Austin), Chicago's drop-off program generally does not accept meat or dairy
Check your specific drop-off location for accepted items
commonMistakes: Don't put meat in the blue cart
Don't assume Chicago drop-off composting accepts meat — most sites don't

materials.name: Dairy products
instructions: Pour expired milk down drain
Food waste goes in trash (black cart) — most Chicago food scrap drop-offs do not accept dairy
Rinse and recycle the container in the blue cart
notes: Separate the container (recyclable) from the dairy product (trash)
commonMistakes: Don't put dairy food waste in blue cart
Rinse containers before recycling

materials.name: Bread and grains
instructions: Take to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location
Bread and grain products are accepted at drop-off sites
If no drop-off is convenient, place in trash (black cart)
notes: Bread and grains break down easily in composting
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the blue cart

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in brown yard waste cart (provided seasonally by the city)
Chicago collects yard waste from April through November
Branches must be cut to 4 feet or shorter and bundled
Leaves and grass go loose in the brown cart — no plastic bags
notes: Chicago provides seasonal brown yard waste carts for curbside collection April–November
Yard waste is composted by the city
Outside the April–November season, yard waste goes in the black trash cart
commonMistakes: Don't put yard waste in plastic bags — use paper bags or place loose in brown cart
Don't put yard waste in the blue recycling cart
Don't mix food scraps with yard waste in the brown cart

materials.name: Leaves
instructions: Place loose in brown yard waste cart (April–November)
Use paper yard waste bags if you don't have a brown cart
Do NOT use plastic bags
notes: Chicago collects leaves as part of the seasonal yard waste program
commonMistakes: Don't bag leaves in plastic — use paper bags or put loose in brown cart

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Take to the Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Tape terminals of lithium-ion and 9V batteries before transport to prevent short circuits
Do NOT put in trash or blue cart
notes: The facility at 1150 N. North Branch St. is free for Chicago residents
Batteries can cause fires in garbage trucks and recycling facilities
Some retailers like Best Buy and Home Depot also accept rechargeable batteries
commonMistakes: Never throw batteries in trash — fire risk
Don't put batteries in the blue cart

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
instructions: Take to the Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Delete personal data before disposal
Best Buy also accepts many electronics for recycling
notes: The facility at 1150 N. North Branch St. accepts computers, monitors, TVs, printers, and other electronics for free
Open Tuesday through Saturday for Chicago residents
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in trash or blue cart
Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Smartphone / cell phone
instructions: Factory reset and remove SIM card
Trade in at carrier stores (AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile) or Apple/Samsung for credit
Or take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Best Buy also accepts phones for recycling
notes: Many carrier stores on Michigan Ave and throughout Chicago offer trade-in programs
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data and remove SIM card
Don't throw phones in the trash

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent bulbs: take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
LED bulbs: also accepted at the facility or Best Buy
Incandescent bulbs: wrap in paper and place in trash (black cart)
notes: CFL and fluorescent bulbs contain mercury and must not go in trash
Home Depot and Lowe's in Chicago also accept CFL bulbs for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent bulbs in trash — mercury hazard
Don't put any light bulbs in the blue cart

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Handle carefully — do not break
Transport upright if possible
notes: Contains mercury — hazardous if broken
Home Depot stores in Chicago also accept fluorescent tubes
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash or blue cart
Don't break — mercury vapor is hazardous

materials.name: Motor oil and automotive fluids
instructions: Take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
AutoZone and O'Reilly Auto Parts in Chicago also accept used motor oil for free
notes: Never pour oil down drains or into alleys
Most auto parts stores accept used oil
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drains or storm sewers
Don't mix different automotive fluids together

materials.name: Household chemicals and cleaners
instructions: Take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Do not mix chemicals together
Transport in original containers when possible
notes: The facility accepts a wide range of household hazardous chemicals for free
Never pour chemicals down drains or into storm sewers
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — chemical containers can leak and are hazardous
Don't pour down drains

materials.name: Propane tanks
instructions: Take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Never put in trash, blue cart, or black cart
notes: Pressurized containers are fire and explosion risks in garbage trucks
commonMistakes: Never puncture or try to empty by force
Don't put in any curbside cart

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Take to a Chicago police district station drug take-back box
Walgreens and CVS in Chicago participate in drug take-back programs
If no drop-off: mix with coffee grounds or kitty litter, seal in a container, and place in trash
notes: Chicago PD has permanent drug take-back boxes at district stations
Do not flush medications — this contaminates water
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications down the toilet
Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate wearable items to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or Chicago thrift stores
Place in textile recycling bins (found at many locations citywide)
Worn-out textiles and linens are still accepted in textile bins for fiber recycling
If not donatable: place in trash
Do NOT put in blue cart
notes: Clothes and linens are explicitly listed as NOT accepted in Chicago's blue cart
Chicago has numerous textile drop-off bins and thrift stores throughout the city
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing or fabric in the blue recycling cart
Don't put in trash if it can be donated or taken to textile recycling

materials.name: Damaged or worn-out clothing / textiles
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Donate or use textile recycling if still usable
notes: Non-donatable clothing goes in regular trash in Chicago
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Plastic bags (store drop-off recycling)
instructions: Collect clean, dry plastic bags and film
Take to Jewel-Osco, Mariano's, Target, or Walmart store drop-off bins
Accepted: grocery bags, produce bags, bread bags, dry cleaning bags, newspaper sleeves, bubble wrap
notes: Do NOT put plastic bags in the blue cart — they must go to store drop-off
Many Chicago grocery stores have collection bins near the entrance
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic bags in the blue cart — ever
Bags must be clean and dry

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Collect in a sealed container
Take to a Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off location or the facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Never pour down the drain — cooking oil causes sewer blockages
notes: Pouring grease down Chicago drains contributes to sewer backups
Some restaurants accept used cooking oil
commonMistakes: Never pour down sink or storm drains
Don't put liquid oil in the trash without sealing it first

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Thermal paper contains BPA and cannot be recycled
notes: Thermal receipts contaminate paper recycling with BPA chemicals
If a receipt is plain paper (not shiny/slick), it can be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in the blue cart

materials.name: Pet waste
instructions: Bag and place in trash (black cart)
Do NOT compost or recycle pet waste
notes: Pet waste contains harmful pathogens
Not accepted at Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off locations
commonMistakes: Never put in blue cart
Never compost pet waste

materials.name: Bubble wrap and packing materials
instructions: Styrofoam packing peanuts: trash (black cart)
Plastic bubble wrap and air pillows: take to store drop-off with plastic bags, or trash
Do NOT put in blue cart
notes: Plastic film and foam jam recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put bubble wrap or packing peanuts in the blue cart

materials.name: Mirrors and window glass
instructions: Wrap carefully in newspaper or cardboard
Place in trash (black cart)
Label as BROKEN GLASS for safety
notes: Mirror glass and window glass have different chemical compositions than bottle glass and cannot be recycled together
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors or window glass in the blue cart
Don't confuse with recyclable glass bottles/jars

materials.name: Ceramics and pottery
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Donate usable items to thrift stores
notes: Ceramics contaminate glass recycling and must not go in the blue cart
commonMistakes: Don't put ceramics in with glass recycling
Broken ceramics should be wrapped for safety

materials.name: Fast food wrappers
instructions: Greasy/food-soiled fast food wrappers: trash (black cart)
Clean paper wrappers with no grease: blue cart
notes: Chicago does not have curbside composting, so food-soiled paper goes in trash for most residents
Clean paper can be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy wrappers in the blue cart

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Wax-coated paper is not recyclable
Can take to Food Scrap Drop-Off locations if accepted at your site
notes: Wax coating prevents paper recycling
Without curbside composting, this is trash for most Chicago residents
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Paper towels and tissues
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Paper fibers are too short and contaminated to recycle
notes: Paper towels and tissues cannot be recycled regardless of condition
Can be taken to Food Scrap Drop-Off locations for composting if clean/food-soiled only
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer — most accept old tires when you buy new ones
Or take to a licensed tire recycler
Do NOT put in trash or at the curb
notes: Illinois law restricts tire disposal — they cannot go in regular trash
Check with local tire shops for disposal options
commonMistakes: Don't dump tires illegally — fines are steep in Chicago

materials.name: Mattress and box spring
instructions: Schedule a bulk pickup through Chicago 311 (call 311 or use the CHI 311 app)
Place at the curb on your scheduled pickup day
Or arrange private hauling
notes: Chicago offers bulk item pickup by request through 311
Do not leave at curb without scheduling — you may be fined
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without a scheduled pickup

materials.name: Large / bulk items
instructions: Schedule bulk pickup through Chicago 311 (call 311 or use the CHI 311 app)
Place at curb on your scheduled collection day
Appliances with refrigerant (AC units, fridges) require special handling
notes: Chicago provides bulk pickup service through the 311 system
Usable furniture can be donated to Habitat for Humanity ReStore or thrift stores
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling — can result in a fine
Don't put appliances with refrigerant at curb without notifying 311

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to Best Buy or Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Do NOT put in blue cart
notes: Cables and cords tangle in recycling machinery and damage equipment
commonMistakes: Never put cables or cords in curbside recycling

materials.name: Ink and toner cartridges
instructions: Return to Staples or Office Depot — Chicago has many locations
Manufacturer mail-back programs (HP, Canon, Epson) also available
Take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
notes: Some stores give rewards credit for cartridge returns
commonMistakes: Don't throw in trash — ink can leak
Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container or a heavy plastic container (like a laundry detergent bottle)
Take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility at 1150 N. North Branch St.
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Loose sharps are dangerous to sanitation workers
Seal the container and label it SHARPS
commonMistakes: Never put sharps loose in trash or recycling
Don't overfill sharps containers

materials.name: Makeup and cosmetics
instructions: Most cosmetics packaging: trash (black cart)
Clean, empty #1/#2/#5 plastic bottles (lotion, shampoo): rinse and recycle in blue cart
Nail polish: take to Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility (hazardous)
notes: Small cosmetics containers often fall through recycling sorting screens
Nail polish is considered hazardous waste
commonMistakes: Don't put small cosmetics tubes in blue cart
Nail polish bottles are hazardous — don't put in regular trash

materials.name: Toothbrush
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Mixed/unnumbered plastic — not recyclable in Chicago
notes: Toothbrushes are explicitly in the category of unnumbered plastics not accepted in Chicago recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in blue cart

materials.name: Coffee pods / K-Cups
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Multi-material packaging (plastic, foil, coffee grounds) is not recyclable as-is in Chicago
notes: Some brands offer mail-back recycling programs (Nespresso, TerraCycle)
If you peel off the foil, empty the grounds, and rinse the cup, the #5 plastic cup may be recyclable — but it's small and often falls through sorting
commonMistakes: Don't put whole pods in the blue cart

materials.name: Prescription bottles
instructions: Empty completely and remove label if desired
Rinse
Place loose in blue cart — they are typically #5 plastic
notes: Most prescription bottles are #5 polypropylene and are accepted in Chicago's blue cart
commonMistakes: Remove all medication before recycling
Don't recycle bottles with medication still in them

materials.name: Detergent and cleaning product bottles
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap/trigger sprayer
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Most detergent and cleaning bottles are #1 or #2 plastic, accepted in Chicago recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles that still contain product

materials.name: Snacks and candy (the food itself)
instructions: The food itself: trash (black cart), or take to a Food Scrap Drop-Off location
The wrapper: trash (black cart)
notes: Without curbside composting, unwanted food goes in trash for most Chicago residents
Food Scrap Drop-Off sites accept most plant-based food scraps
commonMistakes: Don't put food in the blue cart
Don't put wrappers in recycling

materials.name: Condiments and sauces
instructions: The sauce/condiment: trash (black cart) or Food Scrap Drop-Off
The bottle/container: empty, rinse, and recycle in blue cart if #1-#5 or #7, or glass
notes: Separate container from contents — recycle the container, trash or compost the food
commonMistakes: Don't recycle bottles with sauce still in them — rinse first

materials.name: Frozen food boxes
instructions: Place in trash (black cart)
Frozen food boxes have a moisture-resistant coating that prevents recycling
notes: The wax or plastic coating on frozen food packaging makes it non-recyclable
This is different from regular cereal boxes which ARE recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put frozen food boxes in the blue cart — they look like paperboard but have a coating

materials.name: Paper plates and bowls
instructions: Food-soiled paper plates: trash (black cart)
Clean unused paper plates: blue cart (if uncoated)
notes: Chicago does not have curbside composting, so food-soiled paper products go in trash for most residents
Wax or plastic-coated paper plates go in trash regardless
commonMistakes: Don't put food-soiled plates in the blue cart

materials.name: Aluminum pie tins and trays
instructions: Clean off all food residue
Place loose in blue cart
notes: Aluminum pie tins and trays are specifically listed as accepted in Chicago's blue cart program
commonMistakes: Must be clean — heavily soiled aluminum trays go in trash

materials.name: Milk jugs and water jugs
instructions: Empty and rinse
Replace cap
Place loose in blue cart
notes: HDPE (#2) plastic jugs are highly recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include jugs with liquid still in them

recycle: Aluminum cans, foil (clean), and pie tins
Newspaper, office paper, junk mail, magazines, catalogs
Phone books, paper bags, file folders
Paper towel and toilet paper rolls
compost: Yard waste — grass, leaves, branches (brown cart, April–November only)
Note: Chicago does NOT have curbside food scrap composting
trash: Plastic bags, film, and wrap (or take to store drop-off)
Hard reusable plastic bottles (Nalgene, baby bottles)
Clothes and linens (donate or textile recycling instead)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags, film, and flexible wrappers
compost: Food scraps (no curbside composting — use drop-off program or trash)
Meat, dairy, and bones (not accepted at most drop-off locations)

tips: All recyclables go LOOSE in the blue cart — never bag them in plastic bags
When in doubt, throw it out — contamination hurts the whole recycling load
Rinse containers — they don't need to be spotless, just reasonably clean
Flatten cardboard and cereal boxes to save space
Chicago accepts glass curbside — bottles and jars go right in the blue cart
Only plastics #1-#5 and #7 are accepted — no #6/styrofoam
Leave bottle caps ON their bottles
Yard waste goes in the brown cart April through November only
Food scraps can go to the Food Scrap Drop-Off program at library and DSS locations
Hazardous waste and electronics go to 1150 N. North Branch St. — free for residents
Schedule bulk pickups through Chicago 311 (call or use the CHI 311 app)

locations.name: Household Chemicals & Computer Recycling Facility
locations.address: 1150 N. North Branch St., Chicago, IL 60642
locations.notes: Free for Chicago residents. Bring proof of residency. No commercial or business waste.

locations.name: Chicago Food Scrap Drop-Off Program
locations.address: 33 locations citywide (Chicago Public Library branches and DSS facilities)
locations.hours: Varies by location — check chicago.gov for current sites and hours
locations.notes: Most sites do NOT accept meat, dairy, or bones. Bring scraps in a compostable bag or reusable container.

locations.name: Chicago 311 Bulk Pickup Service
locations.hours: Schedule via 311 phone line or CHI 311 app
locations.notes: Free for Chicago residents. Items must be placed at curb on scheduled day.
